channel.title: Babylon Burning
channel.description: Babylon Burning specializes in reggae music, new and old - from the rocksteady of the late 60s, through the roots and rockers era of the 70s, to the foundation dancehall sounds of the early 80s, right up to the freshest releases from Jamaica and around the world.

item.title: keep on rising
item.description: Featuring more from the new Chronixx album Exile; new tunes from Alborosie, Micah Shemaiah, and Medisun; the Golden Hour riddim from Bambino Musik; and revisiting the Nylon riddim from Juke Boxx productions by special request.
item.author: Jesse I

item.title: weather the storm
item.description: Paying respects to the late singer Vivian Jones (1957-2025), and legendary Jamaican broadcaster Barry G (1955-2025). Also featuring a heap of Echo Minott ahead of his Melbourne show,  and new music from the likes of Skygrass, Busy Signal, Buju Banton, Bounty Killer, Naomi Cowan, Ka$e, Hector Roots Lewis, Ras Teo, Iotosh, Inna Vision & Ini Kamoze.
item.author: Jesse I

item.title: after the storm
item.description: Featuring the Scotch riddim from Treydrumz & BlakYaad Productions, and new music from Chronixx, Alborosie, Eesah, Bugle, Agent Sasco, and more...
item.author: Jesse I

item.title: Babylon Burning presented by Lloyd Briggs
item.author: Jesse I

item.title: play skillfully
item.description: Featuring new music from Perfect Giddimani, Chronixx, Jahzara, Roe Summerz, Rik Jam, Roberto Sanchez, Popcaan and nuff more... plus the usual vintage classics in the first hour.
item.author: Jesse I

item.title: many rivers to cross
item.description: Paying respect to the legendary Jimmy Cliff (1944-2025) who passed away on 24 November at the age of 81. Plus new music from Kabaka Pyramid, Khalia, Richie Spice, Haile, Buju Banton and Vybz Kartel; and a spotlight on Badda General ahead of his performance next weekend at the Jamaican Music and Food Festival.
item.author: Jesse I

item.title: Babylon Burning presented by Sista Sara
item.author: Jesse I

item.title: weapon of choice
item.description: Featuring some serious new tunes from YT; new vintage-sounding music from Joe Yorke, Marina P & The Co-operators, Roberto Sanchez & Lone Ark, and Ines Pardo; a new album from Nick Sefakis; some classics on the Entertainment riddim; and some oldies from Stranger Cole ahead of his Melbourne show.
item.author: Jesse I

item.title: silver tongue show
item.description: Featuring new music from Yeza, Akae Beka, Marcus I, I Man Cruz, Roberto Sanchez and Lone Ark; revisiting the Rootsman riddim by special request; and some serious roots classics.
item.author: Jesse I

item.title: the best reggae of 2025
item.description:
JESSE I'S BEST OF 2025 REGGAE REVIEW
 
2025 was a strong year for reggae music, with many excellent album releases. My pick for album of the year is Chronixx’s “Exile”, which comes as a bit of a surprise - partly because he has been notably absent in recent years, but also because I found the album a bit underwhelming on first listen. Somehow I came to enjoy it more and more on repeated listens, until it became a favourite. It’s not exactly the album I was hoping for, as it’s a different Chronixx sound compared to that of 10-12 years ago, but I love how it harkens back to older eras of reggae music - some songs sound like they could have been produced by Joe Gibbs in the mid 70s, while others sound like they could have come from an Island-era Wailers session or even an early 80s Roots Radics-backed rub-a-dub session. I found his 2017 album “Chronology” a bit overproduced, but “Exile” goes the other direction, and I think the more raw approach works here - it’s a great album and a welcome return from one of modern reggae’s greatest.
 
My other favourite albums this year were Rik Jam’s “The Genesis”, Lutan Fyah’s “Strength & Resilience”, Keznamdi’s “Blxxd & Fyah”, Lila Ike’s “Treasure Self Love”, Yeza’s “Star of the East” and Perfect Giddimani’s “Sibusiso”. I mentioned Rik Jam as a breakthrough artist in 2024, and it was great to see him follow up with more great material in 2025. If I was pressed to pick a single song as my favourite for the year, his song “Give Praise” would probably be it.
 
Dahvid Slur has also been around for a few years now, but he stepped it up again this year, and his great EP “Give It Your All” also deserves mention. Both he and Perfect Giddimani benefited from sweet riddims from Spain’s Sinky Beatz, who has really cemented his place as a top-tier reggae producer.
 
Speaking of top-tier producers, St Croix’s Laurent “Tippy” Alfred produced Lutan Fyah’s album “Strength & Resilience”, which is probably the best LP of Lutan’s decades-long career. Bucking the common trend of reggae artists dropping off as they age, Lutan Fyah seems to be aging like a fine wine, getting better if anything.
 
Lila Iké’s “Treasure Self Love” was a long time coming - a full 5 years since her debut “The ExPerience” - but it didn’t disappoint. Not every song connected for me personally, but there were enough that did, and on a dancehall tip as well as reggae. Lila’s musical mentor Protoje had a fairly quiet year, but his tune “Big 45” was a proper modern roots hit. Fellow “reggae revival” heavyweight Kabaka Pyramid didn’t release much either, but his “Show Love” was a lyrical favourite of mine. UK artist YT also penned some serious lyrics in 2025, and he was one of the few artists in reggae to directly address the ongoing genocides in Gaza, Sudan and the Congo.
 
Dezarie’s album “Guardian” actually came out in late 2024, but it somehow went under the radar for me last year. Her song “Hold On” was a huge favourite for me this year, so I had to include it, despite it technically being a 2024 release.
 
HONOURABLE MENTIONS:

item.title: The biggest and best dancehall of 2025
item.author: Jesse I
